contextId.information: Doing this represents preparing the people for the Lord's arrival. AT: "will prepare the people for your arrival"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
John is comparing himself to a servant to show how great Jesus is. AT: "I am not even worthy to do the lowly task of removing his shoes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am not worthy even to stoop down to untie the strap of his sandals

contextId.information: This metaphor compares John's baptism with water to the future baptism with of the Holy Spirit. This means John's baptism only symbolically cleanses people of their sins. The baptism by the Holy Spirit will truly cleanse people of their sins. If possible, use the word "baptize" in your translation to keep the comparison to John's baptism. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: but he will baptize you with the Holy Spirit

contextId.information: This metaphor means Simon and Andrew will teach people God's true message, so others will also follow Jesus. AT: "I will teach you to gather men to me like you gather fish" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will make you fishers of men

contextId.information: This metaphor describes how the Pharisees were unwilling to have compassion on the man with the withered hand. AT: "they were unwilling to have compassion on the man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This phrase is a metaphor meaning that the people will no longer be united and they will fall. AT: "cannot endure" or "will fall"(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
"And some people are like the seeds." Jesus begins to explain how some people are like the seeds that fell on the rocky soil. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This is a comparison to the young plants that have very shallow roots. This metaphor means that the people were first excited when they received the word, but they were not strongly devoted to it. AT: "And they are like the young plants that have no roots" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They have no root in themselves

contextId.information: In this parable, "endure" means "believe." AT: "continue in their belief" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Jesus begins to explain how some people are like the seeds that fell among the thorns. AT: "And other people are like the seeds that were sown among the thorns" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The others are the ones that were sown among the thorns

contextId.information: As Jesus continues to talk about people who are like the seeds that fell among the thorns, he explains what the desires and worries do to the word in their lives. AT: "enter in and choke the word in their lives like thorns choke young plants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: enter in and choke the word

contextId.information: Jesus begins to explain how some people are like the seeds that were sown in good soil. AT: "like the seeds that were sown in the good soil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: those that were sown in the good soil

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) Jesus is talking about a literal measure and giving generously to others or 2) this is a metaphor in which Jesus speaks of "understanding" as if it were "measuring" (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for with the measure with which you measure

contextId.information: Here Jesus is speaking to his disciples in a metaphor they do not understand. Jesus is comparing the Pharisees' and Herod's teachings to yeast, but you should not explain this when you translate it because the disciples themselves did not understand it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: yeast of the Pharisees and the yeast of Herod

contextId.information: Jesus means that Peter is acting like Satan because Peter is trying to prevent Jesus from accomplishing what God sent him to do. AT: "Get behind me Satan! I call you Satan because you are not setting" or "Get behind me, because you are acting like Satan! You are not setting" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Get behind me, Satan! You are not setting

contextId.information: Following Jesus here represents being one of his disciples. AT: "be my disciple" or "be one of my disciples" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Jesus speaks of this generation as "adulterous," meaning that they are unfaithful in their relationship with God. AT: "in this generation of people who have committed adultery against God and are very sinful" or "in this generation of people who are unfaithful to God and are very sinful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in this adulterous and sinful generation

contextId.information: "risen from the dead ... to rise from the dead" or "risen from among the dead ones ... to rise from among the dead ones." This means to become alive again. The phrase "the dead ones" refers to "dead people" and is a metaphor for being dead. AT: "risen from being dead ... to rise from being dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: risen from the dead ones ... to rise from the dead ones

contextId.information: Here the words "first" and "last" are opposites of one another. Jesus speaks of being the "most important" as being "first" and of being the "least important" as being "last." AT: "If anyone wants God to consider him to be the most important person of all, he must consider himself to be the least important of all" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: If anyone wants to be first, he must be last of all

contextId.information: Dying and then beginning to live eternally is spoken of as entering into life. AT: "to enter into eternal life" or "to die and begin to live forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Dying and then beginning to live eternally  is spoken of as entering into life. AT: "to enter into eternal life" or "to die and begin to live forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here Jesus speaks of everyone being purified by experiencing suffering. Jesus speaks of suffering as if it were fire and giving suffering to people as if it were applying salt to them. This can be stated also in active form. AT: "Just as salt purifies a sacrifice, God will purify everyone by allowing them to suffer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: everyone will be salted with fire

contextId.information: Jesus speaks of doing good things for one another as if good things were salt that people possess. AT: "Do good to each other, like salt adds flavor to food" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This is a metaphor to illustrate their close union as husband and wife. AT: "the two people will be like one person" (UDB) or "they are no longer two, but together they are one body" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they are no longer two, but one flesh

contextId.information: The kingdom belonging to people represents the kingdom including them. AT: "the kingdom of God includes people who are like them" or "because only people like them are members of the kingdom of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for the kingdom of God belongs to those who are like them

contextId.information: Here the man speaks of "receiving" as if it were "inheriting." This metaphor is used to emphasize the importance of receiving. Also, "inherit" here does not mean that someone has to die first. AT: to receive eternal life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"My children." Jesus refers to his disciples as "children," for he is teaching them as a father would teach his children. AT: "My friends" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here the words "first" and "last" are opposites of one another. Jesus speaks of being the "important" as being "first" and of being the "unimportant" as being "last." AT: "are important will be unimportant, and those who are unimportant will be important"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: are first will be last, and the last first

contextId.information: Here "cup" refers to what Jesus must suffer. Undergoing suffering is often referred to as drinking from a cup. AT: "the cup of suffering that I will drink" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is a metaphor for being the most important. AT: "to be the most important" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here the author describes tricking Jesus as "trapping him." AT: "to trick him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This means to become alive again. The phrase "the dead ones" refers to "dead people" and is a metaphor for being dead. AT: "are risen from being dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The "heart" and "soul" are a metaphor for a person's inner being and his desires and feelings. AT: "in all that you want and feel" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: with all your heart, with all your soul

contextId.information: The "heart" is a metaphor for a person's inner being and his desires and feelings. "Understanding" refers to a person's thinking, and "strength" refers to a person's strength to do things. AT: "in all that we want and feel, in all that we think, and in all that we do" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: with all the heart ... all the understanding ... all the strength

contextId.information: In this quote, God speaks of defeating enemies as making them into a footstool. AT: "until I completely defeat your enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: until I make your enemies your footstool

contextId.information: Here "lead astray" is a metaphor meaning deceive. AT: "will deceive many people" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Jesus speaks of these disasters as the beginnings of birth pains because more severe things will happen after them. AT: "These events will be like the first pains a woman suffers who is about to bear a child. They will suffer much more after that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: These are the beginnings of birth pains

contextId.information: This phrase is from the book of Daniel. His audience would have been familiar with this passage and the prophesy about the abomination entering the temple and defiling it. AT: "the shameful thing that defiles the things of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here Jesus speaks of not being ready as "sleeping." AT: "find you not ready for his return" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "deeply" refers to Jesus being greatly troubled in his soul. AT: "extremely troubled" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here speaking false testimony is described as if it were a physical object that someone can carry. AT: "accused him by speaking false testimony against him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here speaking false testimony is described as if it were a physical object that someone can carry. AT: "accused him by speaking false testimony against him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This means to kneel. AT: "knelt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here the author describes it becoming dark outside as if the darkness were a wave that moved over the land. AT: "the whole land became dark" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: darkness came over the whole land

contextId.information: Here evening is spoken of as if it were something that is able to "come" from one place to another. AT: "it had become evening" or "it was evening" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
